description.narrative: Dans le cadre de la riposte contre la pandémie au COVID-19 qui sévit actuellement dans plusieurs pays dont le Bénin, un plan de contingence a été élaboré par le Ministère de la Santé. La contribution de l’ambassade servirait à acquérir des masques chirurgicaux pour le personnel soignant.

title.narrative: Activity web page for IATI activity XM-DAC-7-PPR-4000003994

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: COVID-19 KAM Covid Response in Uganda

description.narrative: AMREF Health Africa Uganda and Healthy Entrepreneurs-HE will partner to support 4 districts, health workers and communities along the Northern Transport Corridor to respond effectively to the corona-virus. The project aims to mobilize and build the capacity of a network of Village Health Teams (VHTs) and health workers along the northern transport corridor (Luwero, Nakasongola, Kiryandongo and Amuru to Elegu border) to scale up the efforts for increased awareness, prevention, control and management of COVID-19 and to support continuity of SRH and other essential medical services. The intervention is proposed for a period of six months, working with ~4000 VHTs and ~132 health workers (HWs) from selected ~33 health facilities. The project objectives are: 1. To strengthen a community focused response to COVID-19 in 4 districts along the Northern Transport Corridor. 2. To strengthen the health facilities in 4 districts along the Northern Transport Corridor to respond to COVID-19 epidemic and continue to provide essential SRHR services 3. To strengthen the district level response to, coordination of COVID-19 and continuity of SRHR services in 4 districts along the N orthern Transport Corridor. 4. To Set up and functionalize the Telehealth solution; dedicated diagnostic support line for health workers The activities include: A) capacity building of VHTs for community mobilization, B) deployment of a dedicated and free surveillance support line for health workers (HWs), C) development and distribution of contextualized communication materials for Districts, VHTs, HWs and the general public, and dissemination of MOH continuity of essential services guidelines, D) procurement and distribution of PPEs for HWs and VHTs and E) support coordination and technical support for districts.

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: SAA Reprod Health Commodity Secur Ph VI

description.narrative: Detailed description of the activity The ultimate goal of the proposed program is to reduce maternal and new-born mortality and morbidity in Yemen by improving access to and use of high quality RH commodities needed for providing RH services. Women, men and girls of reproductive age (15-49 years) who are internally displaced or recently returned from displacement, impacted by cholera or COVID related insecurity are getting special attention in this program. Outcome: Increased availability of quality Reproductive Health commodities at Service Delivery Points to support provision of lifesaving reproductive health services in Yemen especially for communities affected by the crisis. In order to make Reproductive Health supplies available at the point of service delivery, it needs accurate forecasting, procurement, in- country distribution and warehousing, a functioning Reproductive Health Information Management in Emergencies System and a functioning Reproductive Health Supply Chain Management System. Output: 1. Coordinated procurement and supply of RH commodities through enhanced partnership and collaboration that fosters an enabling environment for RHCS and family planning; 2. Strengthened national capacities to quantify forecast, distribute, and track the delivery of RH commodities. Indicators and targets Outcome level: 80 % of hospitals providing at least 5 modern contraceptive methods 80 % of health centres and health units providing at least 3 modern contraceptive methods 60 % of EmONC facilities that have in stock selected tracer maternal and new-born lifesaving medicines* required for providing EmONC services 1.000.000 women who have utilized RH services annually in the supported health facilities disaggregated by type of service. Output level: I.1.1. Existence of functioning national RHCS Committees in Aden and Sana’a I.1.2. National RH Commodity Supply Plan in place and its implementation monitored and updated quarterly I.1.3. 752.000 Couple Years of Protection (CYPs) provided annually by contraceptives procured with funding from the program. I.1.4 Quantity by type of maternal and new-born lifesaving medicines procured with project funds according to Supply plan I.2.1. 155 health workers trained on LMIS with project support I.2.2.100 % of districts with at least 1 person trained on LMIS. I.2.3. # of HFs supplied with RH Commodities procured with support of the project. I.2.4. 60% of HFs that receive the quantity of products that they ordered during the past quarter I.2.5. 80 % of HF reporting through the RHMIS. Disaggregated by governorate

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: IFAD has established a multi-donor Rural Poor Stimulus Facility (RPSF) in line with the United Nations socioeconomic response framework. The RPSF responds to the socio-economic impacts for small-scale farmers as a consequence of COVID-19 and targets four main areas: i) Provision of inputs and basic assets for production; ii) Facilitated access to markets; iii) Targeted funds to preserve services, markets and jobs for poor rural people; iv) Delivering agriculture-related information through digital services. The RPSF offers 1) top-up grants to ongoing IFAD supported projects that are affected by COVID-19 and its consequences, on request by an IFAD partner government; 2) Country-specific or multi-country COVID-19 response grants generated by IFAD country teams in collaboration with partners.

title.narrative: Activity web page for IATI activity XM-DAC-7-PPR-4000004128

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: Het Debt Management and Financial System Programma (DMFAS) is computersoftware die ontwikkelingslanden in staat stelt inzicht te kri jgen in hun overheidsschuld en aanverwante betalingsverplichtingen. Het programma biedt ook ondersteuning bij het gebruik van het systeem. DMFAS wordt aangeboden door UNCTAD via een programma dat al lang loopt (bijna 40 jaar) en Nederland is reeds langere tijd donor van dit programma (zie o.a. het vorige activiteitennummer: 28592). DMFAS levert een boekhoudkundig programma voor ontwikkelingslanden en emerging markets om de overheidsschuld correct te administreren zodat de hoogte van de schuld en aanverwante risico’s inzichtelijk worden. Het boekhoudprogramma (downsteam area of debt) werkt complementair aan programma’s van het IMF en WBG (upstream area of debt) en er is veel samenwerking onderling. Een beter inzicht in de overheidsschuld (en de bijbehorende contingent liabilities) vormt de basis voor een beter schuldenbeleid. In de komende jaren zal dit zeer hoog op de agenda staan van lage inkomenslanden (LIC’s). Hun schuldenlast nam in aanloop naar 2020 reeds aanzienlijk toe. Het IMF signaleerde hierover in februari 2020 dat de oplopende schuldenlast een bedreiging vormt voor de realisatie van de SDG’s. De COVID-19 pandemie en de daaropvolgende sterk verslechterende economische situatie in veel LIC’s heeft de urgentie omtrent goed sc huldbeheer en schuldmanagement aanzienlijk vergroot. DMFAS heeft in reactie op de COVID-19-crisis haar online tools uitgebreid (die voor participerende landen via de website toegankelijk is). Daarnaast is DMFAS sinds COVID-19 gestart met extra online trainingen en workshops om de participerende LIC’s extra te ondersteunen in verbetering van Public Finance Management (PFM). Dit is noodzakelijk voor toekomstige schuldherstructurering en eventuele schuldverlichtingsmaatregelen. De COVID-19 pandemie alsmede de economische gevolgen daarvan, hebben de urgentie van de schuldenproblematiek aanzienlijk vergroot. Met stijgende schuldenlasten is het belang van verbetering van het schuldenbeheer als onderdeel van duurzame overheidsfinanciën van LIC’s sterk toegenomen. DMFAS is hierbij een relatief eenvoudig, maar effectief middel om de schuldenlasten van ontwikkelingslanden effectief te beheren en kan zodoende een belangrijke bijdrage leveren aan verbetering van Public Finance Management (PFM). In het bijgevoegde document van DFMAS ‘A response tot he COVID-19 crisis’ worden de extra activiteiten die naar aanleiding van COVID-19 zijn opgestart, toegelicht.

title.narrative: Activity web page for IATI activity XM-DAC-7-PPR-4000004130

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: Since March 2019, AJAR has built a network of 90 women survivors in the camps. The AJAR team regularly works with these survivors, building trust. Specifically, AJAR builds the capacity of survivors in the fields of justice, rights, and accountability. This has increased women’s understanding of conflict, as well as ways to heal its impact. AJAR proposes a 12-month project focusing on issues surrounding SGBV in the refugee camps in Bangladesh, reaching out to some of the most vulnerable women in the camps. This will be done by working with 10-20 leaders from this network, who will reach out to new survivors in the community. AJAR will strengthen the capacity of women survivors to deal with stigma and develop strategies for survivors to be able to provide some contribution to accountability for violation of their rights. AJAR will involve their families, networks, and Bangladesh advocates, to strengthen their understanding of sexual violence and its impact. From AJAR’s experience in Timor-Leste, for example, AJAR will connect work at the grassroots to the international and regional levels, raising issues raised by victims of SGBV and other violations to key mechanism and UN stakeholders. The project has been designed, to the greatest extent possible, to take into account the limitations imposed by the spread of COVID-19, and related government responses, restrictions to travel and access to the Rohingya refugee camps. AJAR believes that there is no time to be blinded to the ongoing crimes occurring, and that efforts to promote justice and understanding, more than ever, should not be neglected. The specific objectives of the project are: ● To strengthen the capacity of Rohingya women survivors, and the Rohingya community as a whole, to deal with the impact of sexual v iolence and to uphold their rights using a holistic perspective on justice; ● To bring lessons on pursuing justice and healing for SGBV from the region to the Rohingya refugee camps and to Bangladesh advocates; ● To strengthen solidarity between Rohingya women survivors, and build awareness on common issues with other ethnic groups, inside Myanmar for a multi-ethnic survivor-led movement to end impunity; ● To provide analysis and recommendations to civil society, NGOs, government, international justice mechanisms, ASEAN, and international actors, on issues related to obstacles to accountability for SGBV.

description.narrative: This activity concerns the second-phase of Education Cannot Wait’s COVID-19 response, which aims at addressing the negative impact of the pandemic on educational opportunities of refugee and internationally displaced children in ten selected countries, with specific attention to adolescent girls, and children and youth with disabilities. The proposed activities aim at ensuring the continuity of learning; accelerated learning programs to allow children who missed online learning to catch up with others; psycho-social support to students, teachers and parents; providing WASH facilities in and around schools; and providing critical information to students and their communities about COVID-19 and its implications for preventive purposes. The total budget of the Phase II of ECW COVID-19 response is appx. USD 19 million.

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: This proposed project seeks to contribute to the realization of key laboratory components of Ghana’s Strategic National COVID-19 Response Plan on quality assurance and data management. Ghana’s laboratories, lack efficient and timely COVID-19 data transmission capacity that will facilitate transfer of test results and data with Ministry of Health (MoH), Ghana Health Service (GHS) and hospitals for a timely response. Thus the application will help support the emergency response plan in Ghana by improving testing and detection of the virus. The work will focus on strengthening laboratory diagnosis including: 1. Ensure adherence to safety and quality assurance protocols within COVID-19 testing laboratories as part of national quality assurance program for PCR testing 2. Provide monitoring and onsite technical support for PCR testing to enhance the quality of molecular PCR testing capacity at COVID-19 testing laboratories 3. Enhance the accuracy and efficiency of COVID-19 test results collation and transmission within laboratory departments and to user agencies such as MoH/GHS, COVID-19 isolation/treatment centres and health facilities.

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: The Foundation for Innovative New Diagnostics (FIND) is one of the six partners under the Product Development Partnership Fund III (#27528). FIND has been appointed to co-convene the Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator Diagnostics Partnership (ACT-A DX) with The Global Fund, following submission of an investment case to the Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator (ACT-A) initiative. The ACT-Accelerator, is a new, ground-breaking global collaboration to accelerate the development, production, and equitable access to COVID-19 tests, treatments, and vaccines. It is a framework for collaboration that has been designed to bring key players around the table with the goal of ending the pandemic as quickly as possible through the accelerated development, equitable allocation, and scaled up delivery of tests, treatments and vaccines, thereby protecting health systems and restoring societies and economies in the near term. Its members share a commitment to ensure all people have access to all the tools needed to defeat COVID-19 and to work with unprecedented levels of partnership to achieve it. The ACT-Accelerator has four areas of work: diagnostics, therapeutics, vaccines, and the health system connector. Cross cutting all of these is the workstream on access and allocation. Under this framework, ACT-A Dx brings together global stakeholders, leveraging their complementary strengths to address the diagnostics challenges that are being faced globally during COVID-19, with a focus on LMICs. The scope of the ACT-A Dx work is significant as it covers the development-to-delivery value chain from end to end, i.e. from product development (R<(>&<)>D for both diagnostics and digital tools); to market readiness of products; to country preparedness for product introduction and uptake; to procurement and supply of those products to LMICs for use. There has been intense demand for COVID-19 testing and a commensurate response from developers and manufacturers. However, this response, with it is expensive lab-based technologies, has benefitted high income countries and has not had any impact for more vulnerable populations in LMICs. ACT-A Dxactivities are designed to address this imbalance in access. It has been estimated that 500 million diagnostics tests will be needed in LMICs over the next 12 months, and that 75% of these will need to be appropriate for use in decentralized settings (i.e. primary health care, community level care). The ACT-A Dx will be working towards this common goal by addressing challenges around availability, performance, pricing, and supply at volume to LMICs. This initiative will also have a ripple effect on lowering costs for high income countries because of the focus of the partnership on low cost yet high-quality tests. The proposed activities will cover five of the eleven work streams into which ACT-A Dx activities are divided. The central workstreams that our funding would be allocated to are as follows: 1. WS1: Develop well-performing Ag RDTs with assured production capacity 2. WS 2: Develop well-performing POC molecular tests with assured production capacity 3. WS 5: Accelerate product development and countries’ test selection through open access resources (e.g., biobanking, data visualization, landscaping, feasibility and evaluation platform) 4. WS 9 : Develop innovative and integrated delivery models to support country policies and uptake for effective test, trace, isolate and surveillance strategies 5. WS 11: ACT-A Dx coordination With this BEMO, the EUR 5 million of additional support for FIND – as mentioned in the letter to parliament of 10 July 2020 (ref: BZ DOC-906517737-64 ) – is operationalized.

description.narrative: The COVID-19 crisis and its aftermath in the developing world presents a case for a dedicated DGGF2 COVID-19 Response Facility to safeguard DGGF’s impact by securing business continuity of vulnerable SMEs and additional funding to current DGGF investees. The EUR 15 million facility provides the Fund managers of DGGF track 2 with additional liquidity to support existing and new DGGF clients through the crisis and safeguard development impact. As the facility is meant to provide the Fund managers with extra liquidity in the short term but not alter the overall (long term) fund size, the amount of this facility will be deducted from the budget of activity no. 26664.

description.narrative: This project aims to empower women leading family agricultural projects and increase their resilience in the face of COVID-19. On the one hand it increases food production, access and autonomy (for them, their families and wider community) during times of severe food and water shortages caused by Cuba’s precarious economic situation and exacerbated by the global pandemic. On the other hand it strengthens the resilience and independence of women in the Eastern part of Cuba that is more prone to gender inequalities by providing them with knowledge and tools for eco-nomic independence and self-determination.

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: JBA COVID Research Agenda South Sudan'20

description.narrative: As the peace agreement is being implemented, South Sudan now find itself facing a completely a new challenge of the global novel coronavirus also known as COVID-19 that originated in Wuhan province of China in late December 2019. Following the COVID-19 pandemic outbreak, the government of South Sudan established a High-Level Taskforce on COVID-19 to deal with the spread of the virus and its repercussions, and also adopted a raft of measures on 22 March 2020 to prevent the spread of the virus before registering a positive case. These actions reflected the fear that a fast spread of the virus would quickly overwhelm the weak health infrastructure in the country, which is trying to transition out of war by implementing the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS). As a result, social gatherings like sporting events, religious events, social events, cultural events such as weddings and political events have been prohibited. This research agenda is part of the Netherlands’ engagement in South Sudan that was formulated in the Multi Annual Country Strategy (MACS) 2019-2022. Within this strategy the Netherlands focuses on: a) Peacebuilding, b) Humanitarian diplomacy, c) Promoting resilience and 4) Women empowerment and gender sensitivity. The consequence of socio-cultural practices on measures to contain COVID-19 is part of humanitarian diplomacy. For the success of this study, a senior researcher from the University of Juba will be recruited to particularly investigate South Sudanese people’s attitudes, or behaviors and mindsets, and response to the social distance guidelines and other measures that the government has issued to halt the spread of COVID-19 and, on the basis of the findings of the study, recommend what could be done differently to contain the COVID-19 pandemic from spreading in the East Africa region, with particular focus on South Sudan.

description.narrative: The agency “Administração de Infra-estruturas de Água e Saneamento” (AIAS) has been created in 2009 within the Ministry of Public Works, Housing and Water Resources. Its mandate is to develop and manage urban water supply systems in 130 small towns and urban sanitation in all 151 towns in Mozambique. This activity is a continuation of the first two phases and will be implemented in 75 towns. For water supply, 50 towns of the first two phases will be supported plus 25 additional towns; for sanitation, 24 towns from the first two phases will be supported plus 21 additional towns. The activity runs from 1 January 2021 until 31 December 2025, with a total contribution of EUR 21.150.000. In response to the COVID-19 crisis, EUR 3.150.000 of the budget is made available for investments in school sanitation in 2021. The overall objective of this activity is to increase access to sustainable water and sanitation services in small towns in Mozambique. In addition to the continued support under the previous programs (345.000 beneficiaries for water and 300.000 beneficiaries for sani tation, to be verified through the PO75 baseline), the activity proposed is expected to reach 157.000 additional people served with water and 186.000 additional people served with sanitation. The latter includes the investments in water and sanitation in schools mentioned above, with an estimated 58.500 beneficiaries. The project composes of four work packages which will generate the following outcomes: 1. A stable AIAS organization at central and provincial level with a capacity to guarantee sustainability of services to attract more funding from third parties. 2. Sustainable operation of urban drinking water and sanitation services in 75 towns under the mandate of AIAS. 3. Investments have been made in the upgrading and rehabilitation of water and sanitation facilities under the mandate of AIAS. 4. An enabling environment has been established to foster smart connection financing and smart water networks to support public and private water operators. The activity includes technical assistance by a consortium of Dutch partners (VEI, SNV, BZRD). Vitens Evides International (VEI) is leader of this consortium, which provides an in kind contribution of EUR 700.230 (EUR 676.038 VEI + EUR 24.192 BZRD).

title.narrative: KAM - ISRHR in Burdened Distr. in Uganda

description.narrative: This joint district based program will improve well-being of young people (10-24 years) and women (25-49 years) in se- lected high burdened districts of Uganda and contribute to SDG3 and SDG5 indicators. The programme will empower young people and women to make safe and informed decisions on sexual and reproductive health and to seek and access quality health services and legal support in matters of sexual and gender based violence (SGBV). It will increase access to and utilization of quality rights based sexual reproductive health services (information <(>&<)> healthcare) for young people and women. The programme will contribute to prevention of SGBV (including harmful practices) and SRHR violations and address gender inequality and harmful gender norms as root causes of these violations. The program will ad- dress the changed context due the Covid pandemic, and include strategies to mitigate the consequences of Covid to SRHR and SGBV. Specific characteristics of the activity are: • Inclusivity: reaching the hard to reach by focusing on hard to reach areas in highly burdened districts; • Integration of SRHR and SGBV services in health and legal response; • Addressing harmful gender norms as root causes of SRHR violations and SGBV, through Gender Transform- ative Strategies; • District level health system strengthening at district level, and strengthening ownership of district level health structures; • Strengthening district level Result Based Financing (RBF) on SRHR and GBV services; • Applying a comprehensive approach (demand creation, services provision and supportive environment) and an ecological model (working at individual, relationship, community and policy level); • Development of a multi-annual comprehensive SRHR/ GBV programme in times of Covid. Taking into account Covid consequences and mitigation strategies in the strategic planning and development of the programme; • Inclusion of technical expertise for feminist monitoring, evaluation and a feminist learning agenda.

title.narrative: NAI - Usawa Na Haki Dhidi Ya Dhuluma

description.narrative: The proposed project Is a one-year intervention that seeks to strengthen the capacity of state and by collaboration ca­pacity of non-state actors to respond and address the needs of sexual and gender-based violence survivors. Key significant achievements from previous (Haki yetu,Jukumu Letu ,implemented in 2016- 2019) in the counties of Kilifi and Meru included successfully enactment of SGBV policies and emergence of women led groups as key drivers of legal and social policy change in addressing GBV and holding duty bearers accountable. In order to sustain these project outcomes the new project adds value to building on these successes by focusing efforts more on strengthening institutional capacity of the women led groups towards ad­ dressing increasing cases of SGBV in the counties thereby resulting in lasting county-based solutions that protect the lives of women and girls. The new activity will also signifi­cantly contribute in addressing SGBV, a shadow pandemic currently and beyond COVID 19 that could potentially erode the results achieved in the previous project or may fail Kenya to meet her obligations and targets on SDG 5 and Nairobi Summit ICPD+25 Commitments. The Goal of the project is Women and girls in Kilifi and Meru Counties live in dignity and free of sexual and gender-based violence. In order to achieve this goal the project has set 2 objectives; Objective 1: To improve access to justice for women and girls by strengthening institutional response of state and ac­ tors to promote and protect the rights of women and girls in Kilifi and Meru Counties by November 2021. Objective 2 - To champion positive social cultural norms, attitudes and practices that promote the rights of women and girls by November 2021.

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: De economische gevolgen van de COVID19 pandemie hebben lage-inkomenslanden hard geraakt. De schuldenposities van veel landen met al slechte schuldensituaties zijn versneld verslechterd. Om tot duurzame economisch herstel te komen, waarvan een gezonde schuldensituatie een onderdeel is, is institutionele capaciteit van landen op het gebied van macroeconomisch en financieel beleid essentieel. Via de African Regional Technical Assistance Centers (AFRITACs) ondersteunt het IMF landen door middel van technische assistentie vanuit regionale centra bij het versterken van hun institutionele capaciteit op het gebied van macro-economisch en financieel beleid om groei te bevorderen en armoede te verminderen. Nederland ondersteunt met deze bijdrage de AFRITACS in voor NL prioritaire Afrikaanse regio’s, te weten AFRITAC West 1 (de Sahel) en East (de Hoorn). De bijdrage is EUR 7 miljoen en wordt al naar gelang de behoefte over beide centra verdeeld

title.narrative: Activity web page for IATI activity XM-DAC-7-PPR-4000004290

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: The PRGT is the IMF’s main instrument for providing concessional financial support to low-income countries (LICs). The PRGT framework entails three concessional facilities: the Extended Credit Facility (ECF), which provides medium-term support to LICs with protracted balance of payments problems; the Standby Credit Facility (SCF), which provides financing to LICs with short-term balance of payments needs; and the Rapid Credit Facility (RCF), which provides rapid low-access financing with limited conditionality for countries facing urgent balance of payments needs. Currently, interest rates are zero for all three facilities. PRGT lending is supported by a model that relies on both loan and subsidy resources. Loan resources are provided through bilateral loan agreements with members. These loans are andsubsequently lent through to recipient countries via on-lent by the by the PRGT on a pass-through basis to LICs. Loan resources are mobilized periodically depending on expected resource needs. Via the Netherlands Central Bank (DNB) and the Ministry of Finance, the Netherlands recently granted an additional loan of SDR 500 million (EUR 602 million) Subsidy resources— which include balances in the PRGT’s subsidy accounts and Reserve Account as well as any investment earnings on these accounts—are used to cover the interest cost of PRGT loans, so that borrowers can benefit from concessional interest rates. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to an unprecedented surge in demand for concessional support from the IMF. In this light, new loan resources worth of SDR 14.57 billion(EUR 17,54 billion) have been mobilized by augmentations of existing agreements with existing lenders and a new one (Australia). To make these loans concessional to LICs, the PRGT’s subsidy gap is estimated at around SDR 2–3 billion (EUR 2,41-3,61 billion) under current policies between 2020-2024 if the self-sustained lending envelope is adjusted to cover LICs’ evolving financing needs.

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: Het Health Insurance Fund (HIF) richt zich op de ontwikkeling van de zorgsector, in het bijzonder op de private zorg en ontwikkeling van financiële diensten die duurzame financiering van de zorgsector mogelijk maken. Het HIF richt zich hierbij op zowel de aanbodkant van de private zorg (verbeteren kwaliteit zorg en verbetering toegang tot krediet) als de vraagkant van de zorg (verbetering toegang tot zorgverzekering). Dit voorstel richt zich specifiek op de verbetering van de toegang tot krediet. Het HIF treedt hierbij op als investeerder in het Medical Credit Fund (MCF). Met deze investering kan het MCF aan private zorgklinieken krediet verstrekken voor: - De aanschaf van o.a. beschermende kleding, medische mondkapjes en medicijnen; - Het opvangen van teruglopende inkomsten als gevolg van dalende patiënten aantal, omdat patiënten uit angst voor covid-19 wegblijven; - De verbetering van de kwaliteit en infectiebeheersing, zowel tijdens de covid-crisis als in de toekomst Dit voorstel is onderdeel van de ‘Covid-19 response’ van het Kabinet en reactie op het AIV advies, waarin 140 miljoen euro extra is vrijgemaakt voor de bestrijding van Covid-19.

The program proved to be effective as a social safety net, and demonstrated positive impacts in terms of household and community asset building.

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: Since 2001, the Netherlands supports Gavi, the vaccine alliance, through project 27598. Gavi is an international organization that was created in 2000 to improve access to new and underused vaccines for children living in the world’s poorest countries. Based in Geneva, Switzerland, Gavi brings together public and private sectors with the shared goal of creating equal access to vaccines for children, wherever they live. In April 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) hosted the launch of the Access to COVID-19 Tools (ACT) Accelerator, a new global collaboration to accelerate development, production, and equitable access to COVID-19 diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines. Gavi, the vaccine alliance together with CEPI and WHO leads the “vaccine pillar” of ACT. Under this pillar, the COVID-19 Global Vaccine Access Facility (Covax Facility) and the Gavi Advance Market Commitment for COVID-19 Vaccines (Gavi Covax AMC) were established.

title.narrative: Activity web page for IATI activity XM-DAC-7-PPR-4000004418

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: RAM Arava Institute COVID-19 waste water

description.narrative: Infectious diseases recognize no political borders, and early detection of outbreaks can help isolate and prevent the spread between regions and across countries. This research project will assess wastewater samples for COVID-19 that can pave the way towards policy tailored for specific sub- populations at the local and regional (including cross-border) level. It will include two main aspects: (1) testing for COVID-19 in wastewater and (2) public policy engagement to develop evidence-based policies to protect public health of marginalized communities. The findings can help detect and isolate COVID-19 outbreaks in the early stages, protect vulnerable populations (and prevent national quarantines), and increase regional collaboration. The Netherlands Representative Office will fund the research component in the Palestinian Territories, while interlinkages exist with activities carried out in Israel (funded by USAID) under the overarching research project carried out by the Arava Institute. The project hence also aims to contribute to increased people-to-people contacts within a challenging po- litical context. The Dutch water research institute KWR Wa- ter has been integrated in various aspects of the project.

description.narrative: The project aims at enhancing the relocation services provided by Tbilisi and Batumi Shelter Cities and Telavi art-residence to the human rights defenders from Central Asia, Russia, Ukraine, Armenia, Belarus, Poland, Hungary, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Greece. The Shelter provides HRDs with safe space for work and recovery, offering conditions for physical and psychological rehabilitation, helping to strengthen capacity of human rights defenders and developing the support network for HRDs through organization of seminars, workshops, and meetings. This project is aimed at improving and widening capacity building program for relocated HRDs, strengthening services related to psychological support (collective workshops and individual work with psychologist) and improving overall conditions in the all shelter facilities and adapting it to the COVID pandemic. The project also contributes to the international advocacy effort for better protection of HRDs. In particular, the project suggests focusing on mental health and freedom of movement of HRDs.

title.narrative: Activity web page for IATI activity XM-DAC-7-PPR-4000004429

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: The Government of Mozambique (GoM), through the Ministry of Gender, Children and Social Action (MGCAS) presented a Social Protection Response Plan for COVID-19. The plan aims to mitigate the impact of the crisis on approximately 1.695.000 poor and vulnerable households. The lines of the response plan include: * an Immediate Economic Resilience Package to current beneficiaries of cash transfers providing additional payments equivalent of 3 months of benefits; * support operational costs of the foster care institutions to provide housing and support to orphans and other vulnerable population; * direct cash transfers to new beneficiaries to provide cash support to vulnerable families in urban and peri-urban areas during 6 months, with special focus on low income, own account informal workers; These direct support measures are accompanied by implementation measures that include Personal Protective Equipment, information and communications campaigns, and kits for people living in institutional care (orphanages). Due to budget restrictions, GoM has divided the plan in two phases. The total cost of the first phase is estimated at USD 76 mln, including operational costs, payment of service delivery, protective equipment and communication campaigns to deliver additional payments to the existing 571.000 mostly rural households and 280.000 new beneficiary households. The second phase is planned to cover an additional 700.000 new households in urban and peri-urban areas, at an estimated cost of USD 150 mln. The Mozambique’s Social Protection System Multi-Donor Trust Fund managed by the World Bank (act. 4000002244), created in 2018 and supported by the NL, serves as an integrated platform for financial support and technical assistance to the Social Protection Sector. Through this MDTF, the Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO-former DFID), Sweden and the Netherlands (with a frontload of EUR 2,5 mln committed to 2020) have already committed USD 25 mln to support GoM in their COVID-19 response plan (USD 22,5 mln to support the proposed Third Additional Financing (AF3) and USD 2,5 mln for technical assistance). The additional support of EUR 4,5 mln described in this appraisal complements finance of the first phase of the Social Protection Response Plan to COVID-19, covering both existing benefici aries and scaling up in areas already covered by the social protection project. It will allow cash transfers for 6 months for 130.000 vulnerable people in urban and peri-urban areas to support their food consumption and resilience.

description.narrative: De nieuwe Surinaamse regering heeft het land in deplorabele staat aangetroffen. De schade na tien jaar Bouterse is enorm. De staatsschuld is opgelopen naar ruim 2,5 miljard Euro en een gang naar het IMF onafwendbaar. Daar komt de COVID-19 pandemie bovenop, die Suriname nog steeds niet onder controle heeft. De huidige Surinaamse regering mist de financiële middelen voor de benodigde apparatuur en persoonlijke beschermingsmiddelen om de pandemie te kunnen bestrijden. Na een eerder steunpakket uit Nederland, verzocht de Surinaamse regering op 13 augustus schriftelijk om een tweede steunpakket. Tijdens het bezoek van de Surinaamse Minister van Buitenlandse Zaken, International Business en Internationale Samenwerking, Albert Ramdin, aan Nederland, heeft M een tweede COVID-19 steunpakket toegezegd van 3,5 miljoen Euro. Uit dat pakket dienen ook de transportkosten voldaan te worden

title.narrative: Activity web page for IATI activity XM-DAC-7-PPR-4000004566

reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: Covid-19 temporary cash program WFP Liba

description.narrative: Lebanon continues to face challenges resulting from the massive influx of Syrian refugees as well as deep economic, financial and social crises which has been exacerbated by impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. These impacts are reversing hard-won development gains, and 45% of Lebanese citizens now live in poverty. The overall objective of the proposed activity is to maintain or improve the food security and increase the resilience of the most vulnerable Lebanese population as well as Syrian refugees in Lebanon that are heavily affected by COVID-19. The program thus seeks to support both Lebanese as Syrian refugees in Lebanon: 13865 Syrian refugees and 1422 Lebanese families (approx 8,532 Lebanese beneficiaries) in total. For vulnerable Lebanese citizens, the WFP aims to provide cash assistance to those affected by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, on top of the current economic crisis in the country. This group is already scheduled to receive WFP food parcels to enable them to cope with the effects of the economic crisis and COVID-19. Given the urban context and the strength of the markets, following the initial in-kind response, the primary modality of assistance will be through the provision of cash-based transfers. This will boost the local economy and support its recovery while providing beneficiaries with choice to meet their food and basic needs. Furthermore, the proposal also sees to help Syrian refugees in Lebanon by means of cash-based transfer modalities, provided through an electronic card. These refugees are a severely vulnerable group, whose situation has been exacerbated by the COIVD-19 pandemic, since many of them lost their (informal) jobs in sectors such as farming, cleaning and manual work due to social distancing and isolation measures. Average income of these refugees has fallen (sometimes completely disappearing): A digital survey conducted by the Refugee Protection Watch (RPW) coalition between 30 March and 15 April, 2020, revealed 85 percent of Syrian and Syrian-Palestinian refugees (200 out of 234 respondents) had lost income as a consequence of COVID-19 response measures. Food vouchers, e-cards, is chosen as the primary modality of assistance for this group as the local market is capable of availing sufficient food for the host and refugee populations alike, eliminating the need to distribute large quantities of imported food. In addition, food vouchers enable beneficiaries to choose their preferred food thereby allowing them to meet their individual consumption and nutritional needs more effectively as compared to in-kind assistance. This assistance boosts the local economy and provides beneficiaries with maximized choice to meet their food and nutrition needs. Through its retail strategy, WFP ensures that its beneficiaries in Lebanon have access to diverse, high-quality foods at competitive prices.

description.narrative: On March 6, 2020, the first case of COVID-19 was detected in Costa Rica, days before the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the condition of pandemic (March 11). On March 16, 2020, under presidential decree No. 42227, the state of emergency is established throughout the territory of the Republic of Costa Rica, due to the health emergency situation due to the COVID-19 disease. In order to coordinate actions for emergency care, a General Emergency Plan is drawn up, instructed by Law No. 8488, which allows the application of resources that are necessary for the agile and timely attention of the emergency. The CNE Board of Directors is the institution responsible for approving the Plan and allocating the resources that enter the National Emergency Fund (FNE) to attend to the emergency. The General Emergency Plan, has 6 components of intervention: • Containment measures • Health system response • Logistics of emergency operations • Hygiene and protection measures • Social and humanitarian assistance • Projects linked to recovery The contribution of the Kingdom of the Netherlands will be made to the acquisition of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE): masks, gloves, gowns, boots and protective glasses to cover part of the component of "hygiene and protection measures" whose value rises up to USD 18,000 ,000. Being this component in which the Netherlands will make a contribution of EUR 150,000 (USD 168.539 –corporate rate of 0.89-), the CNE estimates that there is still a shortage of around USD 709,733.01 to cover the needs of this component. The objective of this component is to prevent contagion through the promotion of hygiene habits and practices among the population and in the development of public service activities of institutions and companies, hoping to contain the number of infected people.

title.narrative: SDG Leadship Lab for UN Res Coordinators

description.narrative: The application proposes a 15-month training and leadership development project for 10 UN Country Teams (UNCTs) and Resident Coordinators (Rc’s) to build their capacity and learning in systems thinking, innovation and collaborative leadership to deliver on the SDGs at country level, with attention to the challenges and requirements presented by the Covid-19 pandemic. Resident Coordinators (RCs) and UN Country Teams (UNCTs) have as their central task to support countries to achieve the 2030 Agenda. Achieving the SDGs, especially in the context of the uncertainties and disruptions presented by Covid-19, will require UNCTs to build yet deeper capacity to collaborate across mandates and pillars and to think differently together about how best to achieve the SDGs. Together, these imply a change of work culture, mindsets and ways of engaging across the UN system and with key stakeholders. It requires bringing together all stakeholders and promote new types of leadership. The 2017 UN System Leadership Framework emphasizes this need and UN DCO has been working with the Presencing Institute to help realize this ambition. In 2018-19, the (then) Development Operations Coordination Office (UN DOCO) and the Presencing Institute piloted the “SDG Leadership Lab” approach with two RCs and UNCTs to enable UNCTs to more effectively work with countries to address the complex inter-connected challenges they face. After positive experiences and feedback, the need was felt to repeat the Leadership Lab with a wider group of countries and this proposal is a follow-up to that.

reporting-org.narrative: International Finance Corporation

description.narrative: The main project level impact is expected to include the improved access and quality of civil aviation services in Bulgaria. The Project contributes to the expansion of Sofia Airport's passenger and cargo handling capacity as well as ground service offerings which is expected to improve operational efficiency and the quality of services. Additionally, the Project is expected to increase the GDP, employment and government revenues through its economic linkages with the production and service sectors, and the payment of concession fees and taxes. IFC is supporting the first competitively tendered large-scale PPP project following the adoption of Bulgaria's Law on Concessions in 2018, which demonstration effects for potential additional public private partnership projects within Bulgaria and the region. The Project is also expected to help to improve the financial resilience of a strategic asset in the aviation sector in Bulgaria, in the context of an unprecedented shock caused by the COVID crisis.

The proposed investment involves providing financing to support the privatization of the concession of Sofia International Airport located in Sofia, Bulgaria (the Project). Sofia Airport is the main international and the largest airport of Bulgaria with 7.1 million passengers in 2019. The Project involves imminent modernization investments and the building of a new terminal before the 10th concession year. Total investments over the 35-year concession period amount to EUR 608 million. The financing will be utilized to fund the upfront payment to the Government of Bulgaria (the GoB) due under the concession agreement and support the concessionaires initial capital expenditures to modernize and upgrade the strategic airport infrastructure in the country.

description.narrative: IFC is considering an equity investment in a holding company (Road Holdco or the Company), developed by I Squared Capital (ISQ), which will primarily acquire operating road assets in India. The Company may also acquire other transportation and logistics assets like parking facilities, logistics infrastructure, and other such assets. ISQ is currently in advanced stages of evaluating multiple operational toll roads to be acquired by the Road Holdco. Update related to additional investment under the COVID-19 response facility: IFC has committed USD 15 million to Cube Highways and Infrastructure Pte Limited (Road Holdco or the Company) on February 15, 2021. The investment is in the form of an A-loan for the purposes of managing immediate working capital requirements and cash flow mismatches of its operating subsidiaries in India. In the current pandemic the Company faces an increased risk due to traffic reduction, 25-days ban on toll collections in Mar-Apr 2020, and liquidity constraints in the domestic financial markets.

The Project is expected to have the following development impact:
A. Support the critical roads infrastructure of the country, which is a priority for the Government of India. B. Demonstration Impact: IFC will create a new investment vehicle which will demonstrate the potential of such consolidation of assets as a medium for channelizing long term risk-averse capital into India for infrastructure projects. The investment will also unlock developer equity and provide impetus to further infrastructure growth in the country. C. An efficient transportation system is critical for sustaining economic growth and the burgeoning demand for passenger and freight movement. A good quality road network will link resources and markets into an integrated economy.

It plans to commission capacity of more than 1GW in next 12 months. IFC together with IFC Global Infrastructure Fund will invest up to US$125 million of equity and proceeds will be used to fund the construction of solar and wind power plants (the Project). Update related to additional investment under the COVID-19 response facility: IFC has committed INR 3,750 million to Hero Future Energies Private Limited on June 11, 2020. The investment is in the form of senior secured NCDs issued to IFC by HFE's wholly owned subsidiaries, Hero Solar Energy Private Limited (HSE) and Hero Future Energies Private Limited (HWE) for the purposes of refinancing their existing debt (New Project). In the current pandemic the Company faces an increased risk of payment delays from power distribution companies and tougher refinancing of existing debt due to lockdown, risk aversion and liquidity constraints in the domestic financial markets.

description.narrative: IFC is looking to provide a long-term loan to support the expansion of Cerba Lancet Africa (CLA or Company), a network of clinical diagnostic laboratories across Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA). The project will be supported by the IDA-Private Sector Window (PSW). CLA, the first pan-African diagnostics group is looking to increase its capacity across the African continent to provide diagnostics services and create well paid jobs in an area with few job opportunities (the Project). Capex will finance the upgrading and expansion of labs in its current network and support acquisitions across Sub-Saharan Africa, including IDA-PSW eligible countries, with the goal of constructing a high-quality pan-African medical diagnostics company.

The most significant Project-level outcomes is patient impact: access to good quality diagnostic services is fundamental in providing improved access and coordination of care. Currently there are many shortcomings across Africa in terms of diagnostic services. There are too few laboratories and those that exist often have poor quality control, with a limited variety of tests. The Project will fill these gaps by (1) increasing the number of patients & collection points. The project plans to expand its lab network to new countries, including IDA-PSW-eligible countries. The project will also increase the number of collection points to the periphery of major cities, resulting in an estimated 0.5 million additional patients and 2.3 million additional tests; (2) introducing more accurate & faster tests: Cerba will aim to expand and strengthen CLA's systems, and introduce new technology, that will lead to additional and quicker accurate testing by CLA's pathology labs, reducing costs and the need for multiple tests, and (3) introducing a greater depth of clinical tests into the markets it enters. This will allow for diagnostics of a greater range of diseases, and these diagnostics will support a greater range of treatments.
Market Impact Assessment - the Project will enable systemic changes by increasing the competitiveness of the diagnostics market in Africa. It will do this by supporting the entry and expansion of CLA into a number of under-developed markets. These markets are characterized by relatively small providers that are under-capitalized and without the systems to ensure consistently accurate tests, as well as by the absence of regulation. CLA's expansion will place pressure on other laboratories to "up their game" and will demonstrate the value of its business model and so could lead to replication by other companies.
COVID-19 - African countries have fragile health systems & to fight the pandemic, public authorities will need to engage the private sector. CLA is the largest pan-African lab in terms countries covered and is uniquely placed to join national COVID-19 response plans. Its labs will be amongst the few labs able to conduct COVID-19 testing.

description.narrative: The proposed Project is an up to US$40 million (under two separate tranches) Working Capital Solutions (WCS) facility to be extended to The City Bank Limited (City Bank or the Bank) in Bangladesh, under the FIG COVID-19 Emergency Response WCS Envelope (WCS Envelope). The WCS Envelope is designed to provide funding to existing IFC client banks in emerging markets that will then extend new trade-related or working capital loans to companies whose cash flows have been disrupted by the global outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic. This proposed Project is a one-year facility, renewable for an additional one year, for a maximum aggregate tenor of two years. This Project will support working capital, trade finance and FX liquidity needs of the sub-borrowers (export/import-based SMEs and Corporates) through City Banks Off-Shore Banking Unit. In addition, IFC as implementing entity of the IDA Private Sector Window (PSW) Blended Finance Facility is expected to support working capital loans in PSW eligible countries under the WCS Facility with a first loss guarantee of up to US$215 million (blended concessional finance co-investment). Without the de-risking provided by IDA PSW, IFC will be limited in its ability to support Working Capital loans in IDA PSW countries given the increased demand for financing and the high risk in IDA PSW countries. This support is targeted in the context of responding and helping with the resilience measures around COVID-19 crisis. The level of concessionality provided to the WCS Facility by the blended concessional finance co-investment is estimated to be approximately 3% of the total PSW eligible facility size, which will be up to US$860 million. This estimate is based on the difference between (i) a reference price (either a market price if available; the price calculated using IFCs pricing model, which comprises three main elements: risk, cost and profit; or a negotiated price) and (ii) the concessional price being charged by the blended concessional finance co-investment. Further details and historical information on estimated subsidy levels in IFCs blended finance portfolio can be found at: www.ifc.org/blendedfinance. As is the case with all of IFCs blended concessional finance co-investments, this project has been assessed against the Enhanced Blended Concessional Finance Principles for DFI Private Sector Operations adopted by IFC and more than 20 other DFIs in 2017. Further information on these Enhanced Principles and IFCs blended finance approach and governance can also be found at: www.ifc.org/blendedfinance. To support this increase in trade volumes at this most critical time, IFC is starting this support through existing clients while remaining open to engaging with other eligible financial institutions providing working capital in emerging markets.

This proposed Project is estimated to provide ~US$110 million of liquidity in aggregate over the maximum life of the Project (up to 2 years) to City Bank, which will then on lend to up to 70 or more export-import based corporate and SME customers and support critical sectors like RMG/textile, Power, Pharma, Chemical, Edible Oil etc.
By sustaining the Banks' ability to provide these services, IFC's proposed facility is intended to promote the resilience of trade finance markets, as well as broader stability that comes about by providing for the going concern of market participants in Bangladesh. Turbulence in global funding markets, among other factors, has made it difficult for the extensive network of clients and partner banks to maintain their role as an enabling platform for liquidity to multiple emerging markets, many experiencing their own acute liquidity shocks while the need for liquidity increases. IFC expects the facility to attract additional private sector investors and partners to support emerging market liquidity, strengthening the market's ability to absorb shocks imposed by the current crisis.

The most significant, expected project-level outcome is reduction in the volume of water used to irrigate a hectare of date palms and an increase in the number of smallholder farmers that receive offtake contracts, pre-harvest financing, and training. Beyond the project, IFC anticipates its investment will increase integration in the date-based supply chain in the Middle East and North Africa, via demonstration and replication effects.

The proposed investment consists of a EUR10 million senior loan to Boudjebel S.A. VACPA, a Tunisian date processor and exporter in Tunisia (VACPA or the Company) to be committed in two tranches. IFCs first tranche will finance much needed working capital to support Companys operations during the COVID-19 crisis and the second tranche will be used to (i) establish a production unit for date juice concentrate and (ii) upgrade its existing processing unit and (iii) upgrade supply chain improvement program (PASA), (the Project). Founded in 1983 by Mr. Mohsen Boujbel (the Sponsor), VACPA processes the collection, packaging and export of organic and conventional dates. VACPA is the largest date exporter in Tunisia, with 10% market share in volume and 12% market share in total value as of FY19. With over 1,600 employees and an access over 1,000 farmers, the Company serves c.100 clients globally across N. America, Western and Central Europe and South-East Asia. VACPA has been the first Tunisian agribusiness company to be certified ISO 9001 (Quality Management) in 1998 and also holds several international certifications in food and environment safety including IFS, BRC, ISO 22000 (Food Safety Management), ISO 14001 (Environmental Management) and Global GAP.

description.narrative: Stakeholders impact - Change in Healthcare SMEs' access to finance and benefits for patients: IFC anticipates that the Program will enable PFIs to sustainably increase their healthcare SME loan portfolio and risk profile and hence, contribute to increasing access to longer-term finance (up to 7-years tenor), which are financially underserved in these markets. The financing will be used to acquire medical equipment which is expected to improve the effectiveness of the healthcare provided and so contribute to a strengthening of human capital. The development impact is expected to be further strengthened with the IFC Advisory Services provided to selected HSMEs and PFIs and the inclusion of maintenance and servicing of medical equipment by the OEMs. Contribution to Market Creation - Competitiveness: The Program will encourage competition among OEMs which could result in equipment prices falling for the benefit of the HSMEs. Through a demonstration channel, PFIs' expansion of their healthcare SME loan portfolios will demonstrate to the wider market in the Program's Countries that HSMEs form an attractive market segment. The Program is expected to increase the market's competitiveness as other FIs in the Countries increase their lending to this market segment. There is also potential for the Program to lead to more loans and leasing by OEMs and equipment distributors. The Program is also expected to support the promulgation of technologies in healthcare in Africa.

The Africa Medical Equipment Facility (AMEF or the Program) is an up to US$150 million unfunded Risk Sharing Facility (RSF) established by IFC in partnership with local participating financial institutions (PFIs) and original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) to support small and medium-sized healthcare providers (Healthcare SMEs) access up to US$300 million in loans and leases with tenor of up to 7 years and finance the acquisition of much needed medical equipment in Cameroon, Côte dIvoire, Kenya, Rwanda, Senegal, Tanzania and Uganda (the Countries). The Program is expected to receive support from the IDA Private Sector Window (PSW) Blended Finance Facility (BFF) and the Global Financing Facility (GFF) in the form of up to US$18 million and up to US$6 million First Loss Guarantee (Blended Concessional Finance Co-Investment) respectively to facilitate the deployment of the Programs first phase of US$100 million unfunded RSF to generate up to US$200 million of loans and leases in eligible countries. This support is expected to enable the Program to rapidly roll out and reach the healthcare sector in the Countries where access to medical equipment has historically been a challenge and in turn led to poor healthcare delivery and health outcomes. Without the Blended Concessional Finance Co-Investment, IFC will not be able to provide guarantees to the PFIs at a price that allows the PFIs in turn to provide access to finance to the health SMEs at a viable cost. Under the Program, IFC will seek to work with as many PFIs and OEMs as possible that will meet IFCs due diligence and investment criteria and are interested to participate in the Program with its defined terms and conditions. Any local financial institutions operating in one or several of the Countries and any OEMs with presence either directly or through a duly authorized distributor in one or several of the Countries are encouraged to contact IFC to explore partnership under the Program. IFC is also actively organizing outreaching activities to contact many potential market participants to explain the Programs terms and conditions.

description.narrative: 1.improved access to quality transport infrastructure and services: IFC expects the rehabilitation of the rural roads in the Region will expand the road network and improve accessibility to the rural communities. This is expected to benefit about 150,000 people living in rural areas from improved access to public transport and other public services, lower vehicle operations costs and timing saving. 2. Improved access to health -related products: the Project will provide funding to meet capital expenditures related to the health impact of COVID-19. This will have a direct impact on its inhabitants' health and contribute to flatten contagion of the virus. 3. Integration through mobilization of private sector financing: IFC expects that the Project will contribute towards further opening up of Morocco's subnational infrastructure financing to private investors by providing a continued strong commitment and signal for potential participants. 4. Integration through improved connectivity and mobility: IFC anticipates that the rehabilitation of the road will enhance physical connectivity and economic integration of Region to the rest of the country.

The Project consists of USD 35 million loan to support the priority investment program of the Region of Fes Meknes, one of Moroccos twelve administrative regions. Proceeds of the loan will be used to fund two components: the first component related to financing COVID-19 expenditures including purchases of disinfection and sterilization equipment and the second component consists of financing regional rural roads targeting underprivileged populations in remote areas.

description.narrative: The Project is expected to have the following development impact: (i) Increase in trade finance for EMIBs and underlying importers and exporters in Africa. Through the Project, BBI will increase its trade finance in those riskier markets and support the capacity of EMIBs to finance trade flows. (ii) Market resilience. By sustaining BBI's ability to provide trade finance services, despite COVID, IFC's facility is intended to promote the resilience of trade finance markets. In addition, it will contribute to the maintenance of financial stability by providing comfort to other market participants, beyond the project, that are under pressure to retreat from African markets during this economic crisis. In doing so, this project will help to protect the essential platform of myriad cross-border trade finance linkages.

The proposed project, BBI IDA RSF is a funded and unfunded 50%-50% risk sharing facility with BMCE Bank International Plc (BBI or the Bank), a subsidiary of Bank of Africa (formerly BMCE Bank), on a portfolio of trade-related assets for up to US$150 million (the Project). The Project will provide BBI with funding and risk mitigation to finance importers and exporters of essential goods in emerging markets in Africa. IFCs investment will also help BBI augment its trade finance delivery in certain key markets of its corporate strategy. The facility will initially have an availability period of 3 years with a run-off period of up to 6 months, while the underlying trade assets will have a maximum tenor of up to 12 months. The project includes support from the International Development Associations Private Sector Window Blended Finance Facility (IDA PSW BFF) as described below.

description.narrative: Bergman, Ross & Partners Radiologist Incorporated ('BRI', 'the Borrower' or 'the Company'), one of the largest radiology practices in Sub-Saharan Africa, seeks IFC financing for the expansion of their existing Medical Diagnostic Imaging ('MDI') practice in Accra, Ghana. The new facility, operating under the business name Quest Medical Imaging Ghana, will initially have one unit each of Ultrasound, Digital X-Ray/Fluoroscopy and CT Scan ('the Project'). The Project will address domestic shortage of MDI facilities in Ghana as demand for imaging facilities in Ghana currently outstrips supply.

Stakeholders: The Project will address domestic shortage of diagnostic medical imaging facilities in Ghana. These facilities play a key role in the provision of health care and allow for the effective treatment of cancer and respiratory illnesses, for example. The quality of imaging will be ensured because BRI, a leading South African Diagnostic Medical Imaging Services Company, will train staff in Ghana in operating and managing complex medical imaging machinery based on global best practices. Competitiveness: The Project will introduce and strengthen access to world-class medical diagnostic imaging facilities in Accra, thereby, improving the quality of locally available diagnostic facilities by facilitating the entry of a higher quality provider.

description.narrative: Implementation of the Project is expected to increase reliable supply of essential gases including Oxygen. An important impact of the Project is that it will increase POL's capacity to produce Oxygen by around 70%, which is critical for treatment of COVID-19. The project will also lead to an increase in the production of Nitrogen and Argon which have important applications in the health care sector as well as a range of other industries. There is also potential for the project to have environmental benefits. IFC anticipates that the Project will lead to increased market resilience, in light of the effects of COVID-19. IFC's intervention will help address the sharp supply disruptions resulting from the COVID19 health pandemic by fully meeting the urgent demand for medical oxygen gas. By supporting a market participant withstand the COVID19 pandemic, the Project will help preserve the market's ability to support the economic recovery effort as conditions normalize.

Originally established in 1935, Pakistan Oxygen Limited (POL or the Company) is engaged in: (i) the manufacture and sale of medical and industrial gases and welding consumables; (ii) marketing of medical equipment; and (iii) provision of engineering service solutions. POL collaborates with customers to provide a wide range of services from supplying gases to technical consultation, design of pipeline systems to safety, quality risk analysis and training for companies in the business of healthcare, energy, food processing, medical engineering, and wastewater treatment. The Company is undertaking an expansion program to add a modern and efficient Air Separation Unit (ASU) of 270 tons per day (tpd) capacity for production of Oxygen, Nitrogen and Argon, and to enhance production efficiencies at its Port Qasim plant and has invited IFC to consider its investment program (the Project).

description.narrative: 1) The Project will increase supply of high-quality housing units at reasonable prices and contribute towards bridging the housing gap in India. Majority of the housing projects being developed as part of the Project are expected to be Affordable Housing (as defined in the Harmonized Master List of Infrastructure sub-sectors issued by India's Ministry of Finance). 2) Growing economic activity and creating jobs is essential, especially to minimize the economic consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Project will create direct and indirect jobs resulting from the construction of housing units. 3) Incremental demonstration effect by strengthening operations of a successful market player in a fragmented, inefficient market.

Puravankara Limited (Puravankara or the Group) is one of the leading housing developers in Southern India, whose business is largely focused on southern and western India. The Group is primarily focused on residential real estate operating under two brands: Puravankara for luxury and higher-income housing and Provident for affordable housing. The proposed investment for an amount aggregating up to INR 5,560 million (approximately US$76 million) - by IFC for up to INR 3,160 million (approximately US$43 million) and by IFC Emerging Asia Fund, LP (EAF) for up to INR2,400 million (approximately US$33 million) would be made in one or more Special Purpose Vehicles (SPVs) set up by the Group, for the development of three or four housing projects under the Provident brand, including the identified projects in Kochi and Bengaluru (collectively the Project). The Project entails the development of approximately 4,000 housing units over the next five to seven years under the two identified projects, in planned and green urban spaces in micro markets with shortage of reasonably priced good quality housing units.

description.narrative: 1) Job Creation: In terms of local employment, IFC expects the Project to create several direct jobs for the two new hotels such as receptionists, cleaners, security, restaurant workers as well as the indirect jobs in the hotel's supply chain and related linkages such as taxi companies and tour guides. It is expected that [XX%] will be female employment. 2) Domestic suppliers: The Project will also include refurbishments of old hotels, improving the quality of buildings and service offerings, which is in line with the Thai Ministry of Sports and Tourism and the Tourism Authority of Thailand (TAT)'s objective of shifting Thailand's offering from "mass-market, quantity" to "high-value, quality". Local suppliers of goods and services will benefit from greater demand for higher volume and from demand for better quality products and services that allow for greater value added. Close to 100% of AWC suppliers are domestic. 3) Effect on employees: On average, 60 hours of training will be provided to a hotel employee. The training is given all staff, even hourly employees, and includes essential skill and knowledge areas such as culinary, rooms operation and purchasing, as well as other discipline-specific skills in finance, HR, IT, loss prevention, marketing and sales. In addition, most of the international hotel brands which AWC use are committed to developing people. Managerial staff participate in management training programs. . By upskilling its employees, AWC will contribute to the mobility of these employees who can progress to higher level jobs in the same company or move to other companies in the services sector. 4) Effect on sourcing: Thailand's hotel supply chain is made up of many small and medium size enterprises (SMEs) including small manufacturing companies and smallholder farmers linked to the hotel food and beverage and procurement value chain. AWC estimates that it procures around 30% from local SMEs including give examples. AWC has worked with local suppliers to improve the quality to meet the standards of the renown global hotel operators such as Marriott, Le Meridien, Hilton and Sheraton.

IFCs proposed investment is a green loan of Thai Baht (THB) 4,500 million (equivalent of US$137 million) to Asset World Corp Public Company Limited (AWC or the Company). The IFC green loan, expected to be compliant with the International Capital Market Association (ICMA) Green Bond Principles, will be used toward energy efficiency measures in the refurbishment of four hotels, the greenfield development of two new hotels in key tourism destinations of Thailand including Bangkok, Hua Hin, Koh Samui and Chiang Mai and working capital to support the gradual re-opening of hotels following Covid-19-related shutdowns. AWC is the key real estate and hospitality arm of Thai Charoen Company (TCC) Group (the Group). AWC is the largest hospitality operator in Thailand by number of rooms and has a growing and diverse portfolio of assets in hospitality and lifestyle destinations, retail and commercial workspaces, with ten retail centers and four office buildings.

description.narrative: The proposed Project is an up to US$25 million Working Capital Solutions (WCS) facility to be extended to Bank Asia Limited (Bank Asia or the Bank) in Bangladesh, under the FIG COVID-19 Emergency Response WCS Envelope (WCS Envelope). The WCS Envelope is designed to provide funding to existing IFC client banks in emerging markets that will then extend new trade-related or working capital loans to companies whose cash flows have been disrupted by the global outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic. This proposed Project is a one-year facility, renewable for an additional one year, for a maximum aggregate tenor of two years. This Project will support working capital, trade finance and FX liquidity needs of the sub-borrowers (export/import-based SMEs and Corporates) through Bank Asias Off-Shore Banking Unit.

This proposed Project is estimated to provide ~US$110 million of liquidity in aggregate over the maximum life of the Project (up to 2 years) to Bank Asia, which will then on lend to up to 70 or more export-import based corporate and SME customers and support critical sectors like RMG/textile, Power, Pharma, Chemical, Edible Oil etc.
By sustaining the Banks' ability to provide these services, IFC's proposed facility is intended to promote the resilience of trade finance markets, as well as broader stability that comes about by providing for the going concern of market participants in Bangladesh. Turbulence in global funding markets, among other factors, has made it difficult for the extensive network of clients and partner banks to maintain their role as an enabling platform for liquidity to multiple emerging markets, many experiencing their own acute liquidity shocks while the need for liquidity increases. IFC expects the facility to attract additional private sector investors and partners to support emerging market liquidity, strengthening the market's ability to absorb shocks imposed by the current crisis.

description.narrative:
Stakeholder Effects: Improved access to and quality of finance for microenterprises and SMEs - The income stream of MSMEs, has been severely affected by the lockdowns, increased uncertainty, and a slow-down in economic activity in the wake of the pandemic. As the economy re-opens, MSMEs need access to capital to finance investments in inventory and inputs to resume economic activity, and to adjust business models to the post-crisis economic environment. The project will further support the implementation of a digital transformation of KMF's products and operations. KMF expects to digitize customer onboarding, therefore enabling a digital and remote loan disbursements and collections for a large share of its MSME customers. The adoption of digital channels and delivery methods have become increasingly important to adapt to customer needs and maintain business operations in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis.
Resilience: IFC anticipates that project will support resilience amongst microfinance and base-of-pyramids (BOP) finance providers by helping the market deal with the growing uncertainty and catalyzing investor response. A rise in non-performing loans, and disrupted borrower cash-flows has left banks reluctant to lend directly to BOP segments. Macroeconomic instability and uncertainty on the long-term viability of their operations has led to increased difficulties in accessing the funds needed to support the recovery and growth of their lending operations. By investing in KMF, IFC will demonstrate to other investors the viability of supporting the sustainability and recovery of BOP financial service providers.

The proposed project consists of a straight senior loan of up to US$25 million denominated in Kazakh tenge (KZT) to Limited Liability Company microfinance Organization KMF (KMF or the Company) to enable KMF to provide much needed local currency funding to micro and small enterprises (MSEs) that have been negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic in Kazakhstan, particularly those operating in rural and remote areas (the Project). As of end-2020, the Company had a gross loan portfolio of US$324 million and 222 thousand active clients. The Company owns a network of 14 branches and 110 outlets.
